text: hello this is chef john from foodie
wishes calm with a garlic studded herb
rubbed pork shoulder such a great cut of
meat i topped it with some romaine
cherry tomatoes served it on beans this
was fantastic and i did it completely
wrong let me explain
i'm going to take this pork shoulder it
was about I don't know three
three-and-a-half pounds it had a piece
of the shoulder blade in there so they
call this bone-in and step one here is
I'm going to stud it with garlic which
just means poke holes and with your
finger shove in some pieces of garlic
just take some garlic cloves peel them
cut them in half or cut them in quarters
and just push it in so easy so I do it
about five or six per side I'm going to
go ahead and add some olive oil on there
about a tablespoon rub it make sure it's
coated that's going to make all the
delicious herbs and spices stick to it
I'm going to hit it with some black
pepper freshly ground lots of it a good
dose of kosher salt remember when you're
seasoning meat this big you need lots of
seasoning some dry tell Ian herbs thyme
oregano marjoram a nice sprinkling of
dry rosemary a little dose of cayenne
pepper and then I'm going to toss that
so it's all evenly coated now when I
mentioned earlier that I'm going to do
this completely kind of wrong that means
I'm going to put it in a pan without any
liquid without covering it without
cooking it at a really low temperature
this went for three hours at 325 then I
turned off the oven see the light went
out I turned off the oven and I just
left it in there to cool for another
hour I didn't want it kind of wet
falling apart moist like pulled pork I
wanted it to be kind of dry and chewy
and crusty because what I did is I let
it cool overnight then I sliced it in
these thick steaks I took out some of
the garlic if it was on a surface I
didn't want that to to burn in the pan
here gave it just a little sprinkling of
salt because what I'm going to do is I'm
going to sear not over high heat
actually over kind of medium low heat
I'm going to sear those pieces of pork
shoulder just a little bit olive oil for
about ten minutes per side till they get
beautiful brown and crusty so what I was
going for here is texture
all right I didn't want a slow-roasted
falling apart wet piece of pork
I wanted a solid chewy crusty piece of
pork that I could serve over some
delicious beans and you know what it
totally worked
I took some baby romaine I laid the
pieces of romaine together so I could
ship a nod which just means kind of roll
up leaves and cut them in ribbons I
threw in some cherry tomatoes I really
wanted to call this pickled romaine but
then I thought that's a stupid name
it's just romaine with vinegar on it a
little salt and pepper and you might be
thinking hey where's the oil shouldn't
this be a vinaigrette no it shouldn't
the pork has all the fat you need all
the oily goodness the unctuous Ness that
you want so this is simply a base of
white beans that I just heated with a
little salt and pepper my amazing not
moist firm and chewy pork shoulder and
then I topped it with my vinegared
greens and tomatoes and that was so good
actually freaking on the internet that
was so freakin good
those soft smooth simple white beans
underneath that aromatic herb rub pork
studded with garlic just completely
